poll_list.title: Ratification Poll for Permissionless Open Market Operations (MIP74) - June 13, 2022

content.content: MIP74: Permissionless Open Market Operations  Preamble MIP#: 74 Title: Permissionless Open Market Operations Author(s): Marko Štemberger (@rema) Contributors: LFW (@LongForWidsom), Sean Taylor (@Sean), Payton Rose (@prose11), Derek (@derek), Brian L. McMichael (@brianmcmichael) Tags: governance Type: General Status: Accepted Date Proposed: 2022-05-11 Date Ratified: 2022-06-27 Dependencies: None Replaces: None Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip74-permissionless-open-market-operations/15095 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmaivXCv   References   DssKiln - a permissionless token purchasing tool; a forum post introducing the module.  MIP74c1-Subproposal-Template.   Sentence Summary MIP74 defines the process used to agree and action permissionless open market operations with funds controlled by MakerDAO.  Paragraph Summary MIP74 defines the process that will be used to agree and take action on a number of permissionless open market operations with funds controlled by MakerDAO. The MIP proposes the utilization of the DssKiln module in order to make permissionless open market operations over a predetermined time period. The DssKiln module can be used for but is not limited to: (i) altering asset allocations of the surplus buffer, (ii) DAO treasury management, and/or (iii) management of possible future funds controlled by Core Units or other bodies of MakerDAO. For example, the DssKiln is able to perform certain actions that the Maker community has previously proposed and discussed, including an alternative mechanism for MKR burning, and/or purchasing ETH with DAI from the surplus buffer.  Motivation The Maker community has had several ideas and discussions regarding potential asset management strategies controlled by MakerDAO governance. The DssKiln module is general enough to address the needs of several previously discussed ideas. DssKiln can be used to manage MakerDAO’s surplus buffer, treasury, or any other assets on the Maker Protocol’s balance sheet. There are other, possibly better, solutions that would require a greater time commitment from several Core Units and other stakeholders in the Maker community. This MIP, however, can be implemented relatively fast. It can fulfill a large spectrum of needs which are currently present. The DssKiln can serve its purpose until a better solution is identified, developed, and implemented.  Component Summary MIP74c1: Adding & Modifying a Permissionless Open Market Operation Defines the governance process for altering existing permissionless open market operations and proposing new open market operations. MIP74c2: Urgent Cancellation of a Permissionless Open Market Operation Defines the processes for cancelling an existing permissionless open market operation quickly. MIP74c3: Input by Bodies of MakerDAO Organizational Structure and Possible Limitations Defines the recommended input from bodies of MakerDAO. MIP74c4: DssKiln For Actioning Permissionless Open Market Operations Describes the DssKiln smart contract and defines the general parameters that all instances share. MIP74c5: DssKiln Examples Describes two specific examples that can be achieved with the DssKiln smart contract: (i) an alternative MKR buy back and burn mechanism, and (ii) periodically purchase tokens for the Maker Protocol treasury in a permissionless manner. MIP74c6: DssKiln Audit Confirms that DssKiln will be professionally audited prior to production use.  Specification  MIP74c1: Adding & Modifying a Permissionless Open Market Operation MIP74c1 subproposals must use the template located at MIP74c1-Subproposal-Template. This section of the MIP can have large consequences on the protocol’s solvency, reserves and its financial resistance. A successful subproposal under this component will result in a technical state change to action and the proposal being included in an executive proposal within 1 month, absent any external factors.  The proposal parameters New permissionless open market operation which amounts to less than 3M DAI (or USD equivalent value) on annual basis or total per duration of strategy at the time of proposal may go into the Weekly Governance Cycle, provided the Feedback and Frozen Periods have been fulfilled. Anything above 3M DAI (or USD equivalent) on an annual basis or total per duration of strategy at the time of proposal must go through the Monthly Governance Cycle. Parameters for permissionless open market operation with less or equal to 3M DAI (or USD equivalent value) at the time of proposal on annual basis or total per duration of operation proposal:   Minimum Feedback Period: 2 weeks.  Minimum Frozen Period: 1 week.  Parameters for permissionless open market operation with above 3M DAI (or USD equivalent value) at the time of proposal on annual basis or total per duration of operation proposal:   Minimum Feedback Period: 4 weeks.  Minimum Frozen Period: 1 week.   MIP74c2: Urgent Cancellation of a Permissionless Open Market Operation Any permissionless open market operation which is implemented can be shutdown by a:  (i) Signal Request process which must last for equal or no less than 1 week and, (ii) Shutdown Process which does not require a Signal Request can be initiated by Facilitators of relevant Core Units. It is recommended, but not limited to, that Facilitators propose the shutdown to the on-chain poll and propose the immediate shutdown directly via executive vote only in the case of an emergency which is time-sensitive.   MIP74c3: Input by Bodies of MakerDAO Organizational Structure and Possible Limitations  Relevant bodies of MakerDAO are strongly recommended to provide input on MIP74c1 subproposals prior to formal submission. Expected bodies input which might be required and their potential tasks:  (i) PECU: Input on audit requirements and estimated cost (monetary and workforce related). Input on recommended destination market or similar (ii) Risk CU: Input on general and strategy specific parameters, input on recommended destination market or similar.    MIP74c4: DssKiln For Actioning Permissionless Open Market Operations DssKiln is a permissionless token-purchasing and disposition module for protocols that need to permissionlessly participate in open market activities. The following parameters are available for definition in DssKiln by Governance:   sell: the token to be deposited into DssKiln and sold.  buy: the token to be bought in exchange for the sold token.  hop: duration specified in seconds. It represents a minimum number of seconds that must pass before the lot can be sold.  lot: the maximum quantity of tokens to be sold per hop.   MIP74c5: DssKiln Examples DssKiln can be implemented to interact with various on-chain markets. The specific operation which the DssKiln module is designed to perform is called a “permissionless open market operation”. Each permissionless open market operation implementation, depending on which contracts it interacts with, requires operation specific parameters which are defined at contract creation. The following are example parameters specific to DssKilnUNIV3SaveStrategy. Other operations may require a different set of parameters;   uniV3Router: The address of the current Uniswap V3 router.  fee: The UniswapV3 fee pool DssKiln Strategy will participate in.  receiver: The destination address for the purchased token.  The following are example parameters specific to DssKilnUNIV3BurnStrategy. Other operations may require a different set of parameters;   uniV3Router: The address of the current Uniswap V3 router.  fee: The UniswapV3 fee pool DssKiln Strategy will participate in.  Note that this operation requires a token to have a burn() function, therefore there is no receiver because the DssKiln calls the burn() directly.  MIP74c6: DssKiln Audit DssKiln will be formally audited before implementation. The audit will be financed  and facilitated by PECU and their existing budget. The probable next technical steps are: (i) an internal PECU team review based on updated use cases and (ii) an external contract audit. These can be done in parallel.  Resources  GitHub brianmcmichael/dss-kiln    MIP74c1-SP: Adding & Modifying a Permissionless Open Market Operation [Template]  Preamble MIP74c1-SP#: Author(s): Contributors: Tags: Status: Date Proposed: yyyy-mm-dd Date Ratified: yyyy-mm-dd Ratification Poll URL: Forum URL: Amount Requested on Annual Basis and Total per Duration:   Sentence Summary  Paragraph Summary  Motivation  Why are you proposing this DssKiln Permissionless open market operation and what does it aim to achieve?   DssKiln Permissionless Open Market Operation Name  DssKiln Permissionless Open Market Operation Risks & Unwanted Outcomes  List possible risks which this operation is exposed to and potential unwanted outcomes which can occur that you are aware of.   DssKiln Permissionless Open Market Operation Duration  What is the duration the DssKiln permissionless open market operation will be used for?   DssKiln Permissionless Open Market Operation General & Specific Parameters  Specify all required parameters for proposed DssKiln permissionless open market operation, including general and operation specific.   DssKiln Permissionless Open Market Operation Amount Requested on Annual Basis, Schedule of Funds Deployment & Source of Funding  Specify the total DAI equivalent amount at the time of writing that the DssKiln permissionless open market operation will utilize. In the case where asset is not DAI, also define numerical amount of assets. Define the schedule at which the funds will be deployed into the operation. Define how funds will be transferred to the DssKiln operation contract: (i) transfer total amount per duration of operation, (ii) vest funds to the operation over time. Define the source of funding   DssKiln Permissionless Open Market Operation Management & Oversight  Specify bodies of MakerDAO organizational structure (CUs, PPGs, possibly others) which will be responsible for managing and overseeing the operation, which includes but is not limited to monitoring and reporting performance to the Maker governance. Define how the above will be conducted and on what schedule (weekly, monthly, etc).   DssKiln Permissionless Open Market Operation Code Auditing & Audit Financing  In the case where an operation is proposed or modified which results in utilizing new code, define who will facilitate the audit process and how it will be financed.   DssKiln Strategy Details Official Contact of DssKiln Permissionless Open Market Operation Oversight Group: The designated contact for the DssKiln Strategy. Contract Email/Handle: The contact details for Oversight Group Date Added: yyyy-mm-dd Operation Duration: Duration of operation Amount Requested on Annual Basis and Total per Duration: In DAI or USD equivalent and absolute token amount Source of Funds for Operation: Where funds will be sourced from Type & Schedule of Asset Deployment: Type and rate at which funds will be deployed Schedule of Reporting on Performance: Rate at which reports will be published Required Audit: Yes/No Source of Financing for Audit: Define source of financing for audit process
content.GPT-summary: The post is a Maker Improvement Proposal (MIP) that proposes the use of the DssKiln module to manage permissionless open market operations with funds controlled by MakerDAO. The proposal defines the process for proposing and altering permissionless open market operations, and provides specific examples of how the DssKiln module can be used. The proposal also outlines the recommended input from bodies of MakerDAO and the auditing process for the DssKiln module. The post does not advertise the proposal, ask for collaboration, or answer questions about the proposal.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
None
None

content.content: Thanks for posting this. I think DssKiln could be a really interesting addition to the Maker Protocol. Two immediate use cases spring to mind:  More efficient flaps By utilising DssKiln in concert with DssVest and pointing the kiln at the burner address we could effectively reduce the slippage on flaps from around 4% to the Uniswap slippage which at present is 0.305% on Uniswap based on the current lot of 30,000 DAI. In other terms, this would be over 90% more efficient than a flap auction at burning MKR. Note this assumes that there would be no added costs to maintain the keeper network to perform the required contract calls. It also assumes Uniswap slippage would be constant but even at a slippage of 2% there would still be a 50% efficiency improvement. @makerburn posted in discord yesterday that we had spent 44.76M DAI in burns over the last 12 months, if we assume all of this had a slippage of 4% (which likely underestimates things given Flappy Friday) that is a loss to slippage of ~1.8 million DAI (or 1,200 MKR at a current market price of $1,500). If slippage had instead been 1% (conservative guesstimate) this would have been ~450,000 DAI (~300 MKR), a great improvement that would deliver value to MKR holders. Further, it reduces the priority for PE to look into using a reverse dutch auction system for flaps as previously mooted allowing them to focus on other tasks instead. It would also allow for a more structured approach to burning. At present we can use the lerp module to target burn rates but changes in stability fee income can mean that the buffer never reaches the lerped amount. By defining a set amount of DAI they wish to burn, it allows MKR holders more certainty that their vote will result in burn happening, while still allowing the buffer to grow over time if sufficient values for hop and lot are chosen.  Re-stocking the Treasury When we posted this signal request to determine the source of MKR used for vesting (mint vs treasury) several posters including @MakerMan and @omahalawyer expressed their support for an option to buy MKR from the market instead. At the time, no such option existed but we could use DssKiln to purchase MKR over time and then send it to the protocol treasury to replenish vested MKR.

content.content: Changed financing of the audit from SB to CUs existing budget.
I am submitting this for the monthly governance cycle @blimpa.
This proposal is currently being voted on. Its RP will run from 06/13 to 06/27. Please vote here.

Hey @rune + @Recognized-Delegates could we consider voting positively for this? Regardless of whether we want to spend on burn now, this is a useful piece of technical and process infrastructure that increases our options in the future. I would rather see future proposals to invest/utilize the buffer into on-chain assets come through a well-defined subprocess rather than through the top-level MIP process. While probably not perfect, this MIP at least specifies a base level of clarity for these proposals, and contains the infrastructure to manage them on an ongoing basis. Further, we could use this process to sell other treasury assets in a well-defined way, if we decided to do so.

content.content: I disagree about having an open ended process for making arbitrary trades, as I think it goes against making the core of maker as decentralized, immutable and predictable as possible. Beyond having a hardcoded and predictable burn engine (my proposed long term design called ember will be published some time next week) I can see the point about selling airdrops. But imo it’s important that a process to do that is as specific and restricted as possible and doesn’t open the door to expanding the scope of the maker core into also using governance for active trading
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party giving entirely negative feedback on proposal

content.content: rune:  doesn’t open the door to expanding the scope of the maker core into also using governance for active trading   +10000 to this

I would love to understand how this proposal was allowed to enter the governance cycle in the first place. I read the sentence summary, paragraph summary, motivation, and even component summary, and it doesn’t mention a burn. Instead, I read the proposal as a governance process + a tool attached to it (DssKiln). But hidden in the specification itself is a $3m buyback program. @GovAlpha-Core-Unit - how is it possible that a sanctioned MIP can hide a burn (one of the most controversial topics in Maker) in a rider?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party auditing and reviewing proposal

content.content: Hasu:  But hidden in the specification itself is a $3m buyback program. @GovAlpha-Core-Unit - how is it possible that a sanctioned MIP can hide a burn (one of the most controversial topics in Maker) in a rider?   I don’t think this is a fair representation of what has happened, and is quite a strong accusation against GovAlpha. This MIP - being voted on here - does not “hide a burn”. This MIP contains a technical description of DssKiln and the associated governance process. If passed it will not commence any burning of MKR. If it did “hide a burn” GovAlpha would have pointed this out to the Community as it is obviously not the intention of the MIP. A separate proposal - voted on separately here and passed - proposed a trial deployment of the above technology which would burn MKR. This was a legitimate Signal Request that was live on the forum for two weeks and highlighted at the G&R. We have precedent for allowing trials of MIPs via the Signal process. Delegate compensation is one example that went through multiple signals and governance cycles prior to the MIP being approved (1, 2, 3, 4).
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party auditing and reviewing proposal

content.content: Whenever a proposal A is up for voting that has a certain effect in combination with another proposal B, that effect should be clearly outlined. And it shouldn’t matter whether B has already passed or not. In this case, I didn’t know about the previous proposal because I was on vacation when it went to voting, so from my perspective, proposal A would in fact activate A+B together. May not be technically a rider, but IMO close enough
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: It’s fundamentally not a rider. They are independent proposals. The trial doesn’t need the MIP to pass to be enacted.

My understanding is that any specific spending of funds has its own process for approval. This MIP74 reduces the timeframe of governance approval depending on whether the amount is less than or more than $3m. Voting in favor of this proposal is NOT approval for use of funds, it is approving a new, more nimble and responsive PROCESS. Hence, the following language is illustrative only:     rema:  For example, the DssKiln is able to perform certain actions that the Maker community has previously proposed and discussed, including an alternative mechanism for MKR burning, and/or purchasing ETH with DAI from the surplus buffer.   @Patrick_J Please let me know if my interpretation is correct. I am supportive of this proposal, but do not intend to greenlight any actual burning via this vote.

content.content: Are you saying the trial will proceed and we will burn $3M of MKR using DSSKiln even if the technical implementation fails to pass? Just to be clear, as there is a ton of confusion in this thread.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Thank you for the confirmation.     Patrick_J:  I will remind you though that you did vote in favour of the trial deployment, albeit in a completely separate vote.   I don’t need reminding of my votes. I am well aware I supported a specific request for the burn. All the more reason I want to be absolutely clear about the issue @Hasu raised. To reiterate my reason for voting in favor of that proposal, I will quote my onchain comments here: Voting yes here is a big reversal. ACREinvest until now has consistently signaled and polled no on burning MKR. In light of market conditions and challenges for the months to come, I favor supporting the views of a large part of the community regarding the burn at this time. You could say I’m placing a new premium on compromise that boosts unity and morale where the trade off is controlled and appropriately risk-managed. I am comfortable with this trial given the limited scope as proposed here and, importantly, in light of recent liquidations increasing the SB over the past few days… plus, the technological experimentation is attractive. Given the brutal price action across the crypto ecosystem, an open market buy of MKR would be a very powerful signal now whether or not in the ordinary course the burn makes sense as part of normal operations.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Yes - unless Governance moves to cancel the trial. The MIP and Signal Request are independent, and the Signal Request was not presented as contingent on the MIP passing.

content.content: Separate but related, what do you reckon would be the easiest process for cancelling the earlier signal request and prevent the 3 million USD expense other than blocking the executive vote it’s in?

content.content: A Signal Request. DssKiln still needs to be audited so a Signal and weekly poll might be complete before that has even finished, in which case we could cancel plans to deploy. If not, because it’s a stream we’d be able to yank the stream via an Executive Vote in the event it had been successfully deployed via an Executive Vote.

content.content: rune:  Separate but related, what do you reckon would be the easiest process for cancelling the earlier signal request and prevent the 3 million USD expense other than blocking the executive vote it’s in?   Only thing I’d add here is doing so should be based on an unexplored point of view or new information coming to light. We don’t want to end up in a situation where we vote on all proposals 2+ times because the losing side wants to vote again. Perhaps the confusion with the MIP is a good reason to bring the matter up again, but would encourage there to be more substance to another signal than “I don’t like the previous vote results.”

content.content: There are multiple SRs that want to actively trade using multisigs right now, so the MIP doesnt really change anything in this perspective. There was the buy ETH one, which even had an option to spend more than 100% of surplus buffer to buy ETH, there is Makershire, there is Optimism airdrop one which wants to manage something with a multisig and there is the recent one which wants to LP AAVE and ENS we hold via multisig and also buy ETH to match the tokens. MIP74 at least offers for such activities without the need for a multisig. I understand if you have a better idea of how to burn than with DssKiln, but still, MIP74 being confirmed doesnt change anything in terms of attempts to manage assets held by the DAO, it only adds alternative option to multisig asset management.

content.content: The ETH one and the Optimism Velodrome aidrop passed already. ETH one was changed tho to from invest to “investigate investing” during the forum poll, after I asked GovAlpha how this will even look in practice, as the investment was based in % of surplus buffer and we had another SR running, which attempted to lower surplus buffer to 54m and burn the rest. So it was not defined which would take effect first, because it was important to understand the structure of the surplus buffer after they would be in effect. Check the forum post here, but check the first version, which clearly wanted to invest and not “investigate”. My response where I comment on how the poll is not appropriate is here.
GPT-discussion-categories: None of the topics listed match.

content.content: The issue is that major delegates just didn’t realize what was being voted on and it kind of just snuck through.

The confusion seems to be about the MIP however rather than the Signal/Poll. I’m open to feedback on how we can do better, but from my point of view, the signal and resulting poll were pretty clearly detailed as a measure for burning. While the vote itself was onchain for the standard 3 days (and it appears some voters missed it) the signal process took place for weeks before hand. This wasn’t a low participation poll either, the vast majority of recognized delegates participated and communicated their reasoning for their vote. Shifting sentiment is a good reason to rehash a matter, but it’s definitely not a good look for Governance to say sentiment is different less than a week later with no new information. In this case it seems a good chunk of voting power did not weigh in, which is an easy argument to mimic in the future considering the lower percentage of MKR in the voting contract. Here’s the poll copy for reference - https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmWCy8Bc#poll-detail Screengrab for emphasis:  image1870×1078 122 KB
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: I want to add some argumentation to why there is a separate SR set as a trial and a MIP, because I see some people are jumping to the conclusion that this is a sneaky peaky attempt to burn. I also want to add that personally I do not see value in burn until Maker is more developed and from the perspective of Risk CU, I am also against the burn. But I can understand that decentralized communities tend to break in half when there is no consensus reached on the topics which are very important to one side. This is why I, with the help of others, posted MIP74, which took quite some personal time. This is not in my mandate, this is completely voluntary. I saw a problem and wanted to do something about it, because nobody else did and I like Maker. After Burban posted his Burn v1, and later v2 SR, RiskCU needed to do something, because just lowering the surplus buffer to 54m is dangerous and not suitable for the current state. It was not clear who would win the vote, but from the start, it was leaning towards yes. So the only option was to ask the initiator of the SR, to cancel it to be 100% sure this is not passing. After discussing the topic for several hours with the initiator, we came to agreement that he will cancel the SR, if there is another SR to introduce burning back asap. I had to keep my promise, so after consulting with GovAlpha, the trial of the MIP as a SR was the outcome of this “deal” with Burban. Just to be clear, the possibility of the MIP trial was confirmed before I promised anything to anyone. Otherwise, the burn would have been proposed using the MIP74 subproposal, assuming its confirmed. All of this is described in the Trial burn SR. Its a shame that people didnt raise their concerns during the forum poll, as the 3m over 3 months could easily be changed to longer duration or lower amount. So to conclude, there was zero sneaky peaky activity and the SR was on for 2 weeks.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: 3 days and it was included alongside 15ish other polls. Polls like that will inevitably slip through with some voters not noticing. That’s fine if revoting is normal, but if the expectation is that revoting will be rare then the timeline needs to be longer and significant budget proposals much more obvious.

content.content: Was "@ Recognized - Delegates " not tagged in this thread? I rely on that for all threads I am supposed to look at.

rema:  Check the forum post here , but check the first version, which clearly wanted to invest and not “investigate”. My response where I comment on how the poll is not appropriate is here .   The call to action was quite light. So there is no investment planned, nor did anyone I know start any kind of work.  This Signal Request is to signal core units that community wants to have them work on the topic. ETH derivatives (stETH, ETH-related LPs) are also included if it make sense for core units. No priority is attributed. An actual implementation will have to go through the governance processes.  Regarding this MIP74, I understand MIP74c2 could provide the solution to the issue (people killing this tech MIP just because of a previous SR that lead to burn). It is not like we are in a rush anyway. DssKiln might be an important piece of tech going forward so it would be shame to kill it for a technicality.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: I want to echo @Hasu a bit here.   When I first saw the poll for dsskiln I thought it was just to develop (the then already developed tech, but I can’t honestly remember now).  When I saw the on-chain coupling the 3M specifically for MKR burn using the tech I was a bit surprised these were coupled together like this. I had already been thinking about burn and after noting the market conditions it seemed right to buy 3M DAI worth of MKR here because we basically pay almost for 1 yr of MKR vesting with significantly less DAI.   Also it looked like this would go off as a DCA vs. a 1 shot buy/burn etc. So yes I agree with some on the confusion regarding the way polling went here, but am reiterating a stance change similar to @ACREinvest in that I think it would be in MakerDAOs best interests to have a solution in place as well as cash on hand to buy MKR should these markets deteriorate so Maker can take advantage of the situation.   CUs in total are still sitting on 13-15M DAI here and we have earned what 7M DAI in liquidations. Personally I would rather have this go to Makershire since we can sink some MKR into a MKR-DAI or even MKR-ETH LP to earn return and provide liquidity.  BUT I keep coming back to something - even a little burn is better than none.   Even if it is 50K month every month unless we don’t have the funds seems like a good idea to do than to do nothing at all.   So I have formally switched on burn to having some, just not a lot and ideally I’d like it to be coupled to a Maker SPV earning return to fund it, or CUs paying back excess funds (funds we never expected to see) or whatever other creative funding ideas we can come up with to fund something that just burns 50K DAI/month month in/month out (this is only 600K/yr) but right now would be over 50MKR/month.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: MakerMan:  I want to echo @Hasu a bit here. When I first saw the poll for dsskiln I thought it was just to develop (the then already developed tech, but I can’t honestly remember now). When I saw the on-chain coupling the 3M specifically for MKR burn using the tech I was a bit surprised these were coupled together like this.   This was done as a test implementation, as we have done for several other more items that should be formalized with a MIP but the community can consider running beforehand. The signal request was quite thorough and had a decent amount of delegate participation - [Signal Request] Deploy a Trial Permissionless Open Market Operation & Resurrect the Burn @Patrick_J posted a little survey for @Recognized-Delegates  in Discord, and we’d love to get some feedback as to how we can make processes and votes more clear in the future. It seems to be that this situation was made worse by some general Governance fatigue which we don’t have a great way to combat at the moment.

content.content: I think we should make a separate thread to discuss mounting an attempt at overturning the burn decision - the problem is to do it with a signal request we have to win a popular vote here on the forum. I think we need to present an alternative to have a chance at that, since just turning off the burn again would be received very badly IMO. Personally I like stretching it from 3 months to 12 months, so we still burn 3 million but we are much more likely to be doing it at the bottom of the market if we can assume it will come over the next year… But would be good with a dedicated thread to that (I’ll make one soon if no one else does) As for MIP74, as I said above I am against putting in place subproposal process MIPs that are not to be permanent, and I don’t believe it is good for Maker to have a long term process for arbitrary trading activity. It should be confined to the burn mechanism and a specialized mechanism for selling airdrops. Perhaps a simple amendment to MIP74 that narrows it scope would be sufficient.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: rune:  As for MIP74, as I said above I am against putting in place subproposal process MIPs that are not to be permanent, and I don’t believe it is good for Maker to have a long term process for arbitrary trading activity. It should be confined to the burn mechanism and a specialized mechanism for selling airdrops. Perhaps a simple amendment to MIP74 that narrows it scope would be sufficient.   The problem is that not having a subprocess doesn’t prevent the proposals from taking place, it just ensures that they will use the higher level MIPs process, which is more general and has less guarantees around required information, templates and implementation. If you want to prevent active market operation proposals in their entirety, pass a MIP that says: “No proposals containing active market operations are permitted to go to vote, and automatically fail while this MIP is active.” Otherwise you’re just choosing the worst of both worlds - proposals with no standardization in their presentation or implementation, that are harder for governance to evaluate - exactly the situation sub-process definitions are there to avoid.

content.content: It seems like this proposal and the SR have too many elements going on at the same time, making it much harder to come to a consensus about. With increasing magnitude, there’s:  whether to build out this open market tech whether to trial this tech with some burn whether Maker should burn at all right now  It seems rather than having another vote bundled in this way, breaking them apart might have the benefit of achieving more clear consensus for each point in one direction or another. I agree that it wouldn’t be a good precedent to simply re-vote on something when people don’t like the outcome, but it sounds like the scope of the vote wasn’t understood in the same way by the voting body, which would qualify for some kind of intervention. Is there something already implemented that might be a temperature check over time on whether MKR holders generally are pro or anti burn? That topic is a bit too general for a proposal, but it would do to have some data on such a major existential question, no?

content.content: Is the tech already done for the trial or is there some additional technical components needed to reuse it for other things?
No, it still needs audits and further review afaik.

rune:  Is the tech already done for the trial or is there some additional technical components needed to reuse it for other things?   It’s built to have different implementations for different purposes, one for buying from uniswap and storing the tokens, one for buying from uniswap and burning, etc. I think the plan is that additional functionality for other platforms and outcomes is built on an as-needed basis. I believe the interface contract and buy-from-uniswap and burn-from-uniswap are implemented but not audited. I believe the trial would use the burn-from-uniswap implementation.
